Larry EllisonThe answer is I think there's no question. You're going to see a lot of database growth – a lot of database acceleration starting next year which we're a quarter away from. But we'll be fine in Q4. Again, its autonomous databases is growing pretty rapidly. But we expect it really to explode next year. And I really do mean very, very rapid growth next year. I'm not really ready to disclose our plans as to why I think it's going to suddenly spike but we expect very, very rapid database growth next year.

Oracle has been a software stock to avoid for the longest time. It has lagged the S&P 500, lagged the Nasdaq and then came 1st quarter 2021 when Barron's featured Oracle on the front page touting their cloud business.Numerous analysts keep mentioning the framework for growth acceleration is strengthening as we exit the pandemic,” driven by both Oracle Cloud and Autonomous Database, a cloud-based version of the flagship Oracle database software.Company raises dividend by 33% and announce a 20 Billion stock buyback.The tide has turned.

SHEP. HERE.......................... If anyone listened to CNBC yesterday after the close Dan Niles was on. I really like the guy. His top 5 stocks for this year were amd, lite, dis, nvda, fb. For next next year he is picking jpm, orcl, energy spider Gan ltd, and Magna, international. His rationale on orcl is that it is sort of like MSFT was trading when it got into the cloud and the stock took off. I have not bought orcl yet, but I am thinking after the Georgia election on the 5th, I may be a buyer of 100 shares of ORCL. I have a neighbor who works from home for ORCL and the next time I see his family walking by, I am going to ask him about the prospects for Orcl's stock. Good luck, everyone. I really like Dan Niles and consider him to be a genius when it comes to tech stocks and even the CNBC host was surprised that he only had 2 tech stocks. (GAN is a software stocks for online gambling---that one might do well, but it doesn't interest me) but I do like the Orcl pick and ORCL pays a div.

Any thoughts on whether Oracle should buy Cloudera? At the $5.3 bil price tag, it would be an easy fold in, but I'm not tech savvy enough to know whether it could be a fit. I just know that finding a bunch of coders, engineers, and programmers is not easy, and Cloudera has a stable and growing customer list that might be of more benefit to Oracle with its stronger business and management approach. There is a 30 day "Go Shop" provision that would allow Oracle to grab this. Thoughts? Thx in advance & glta.

Oracle will be better than MSFT for two reasons. Give it more time to work. And do a more serious job in cleaning out the I'm bedded Chicom spy code. Make no mistake, it is scattered all over everything. They have to vet every line of code and then decide how to proceed. If Ellison sees it as a challenge, his out of of the box thinking can turn the massive chore into an opportunity. For Oracle it opens new markets, not just the old. Becomes a double win from true synergy.Good luck and go Oracle.

Oracle has a new shot on the JEDI Defense contract: Microsoft and Amazon won't be awarded work on the new deal automatically will have to submit proposals - and the government is also reaching out to Oracle (NYSE:ORCL), IBM and Google (GOOG, GOOGL) to outline the plan: "The door remains wide open for the next three and a half months," says Pentagon Acting Chief Information Officer John Sherman.“This is really about mission need,” Sherman tells Bloomberg. “Because JEDI was conceived over three and a half years ago, we have moved to a different place” in terms of cloud advances.

Here is a simple analysis on Oracle. Q3 2019 revenues 9.6 billion + Q3 2019 deferred revenue 8 billionQ3 2020 revenues 9.8 billion + Q3 2020 deferred revenue 7.8 billionSo Deferred revenues went down by 200 million and revenues went up by 200 million. If they hadn't done this shift -- Revenues would have missed estimates. Business is doing bad. Deals arent being signed . Wait to see how revenues tank this quarter.

Has anyone read in Oracle's year end 10-K ( page 108) about their lawsuit with Hewlett-Packard Company? HP was awarded $3 Billion in 2016 plus post-judgement interest, which, according to HPE's SEC. 10-Q, was $3.8 Billion in May of 2019 and growing at $1 Million a day until paid. Oracle appealed the decision and a Calif. Appeals Court sided with HPE in June of this year per the 10-K. The 10-K further states that no amounts have been paid or recorded to our results of operations. They do say that they can appeal to the Calif. Supreme Court, but will that court even take up their case? And, even if they take up their case, there is no assurance that they will prevail.

The time to be bearish on ORCL has passed. Anyone who understands ORCL's untapped potential in cloud computing sees the writing on the wall. Ever since Barron's first made this clear the stock has soared. ORCL is a fantastic company and unlike many other great companies it trades at a very reasonable valuation. Rising rates and inflation won't give the shorts any meaningful returns in a stock like this. In fact ORCL is a very stable stock to begin with. I fully believe ORCL will make the leap into the cloud. It is in its best interest to do so. You should be buying as much as you can right now. ORCL is at a big discount compared to where it will be several years from now.

Trump said his staff are “very close to a deal” and signaled what could be telling support for Larry Ellison, Oracle’s chairman.“I have a high respect for Larry Ellison,” he said. “He’s somebody I know, he’s been really a terrific guy for a long time.”The proposal, unveiled in part, doesn’t call for Oracle to buy the business outright. Instead, the company would invest in a newly restructured global TikTok, with operations based in the U.S., according to people familiar with the proposal. Bytedance would maintain majority ownership and at least three shareholders in TikTok’s Chinese parent company -- General Atlantic, Sequoia Capital and Coatue Management -- would take stakes in the new business, said the people, all of whom asked not to be identified because the terms aren’t finalized.Oracle’s proposal lacks the payment to the U.S. government that the president has insisted be the condition of any deal, according to two people familiar with the plan. Yet the company will try to use the promise of creating 20,000 new jobs through the popular video app as a way to win his approval, they said.Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, who has played a central role in brokering a deal that would shift the Chinese-owned video app’s U.S. operations over to an American company, leads the Committee on Foreign Investment in the U.S., or Cfius, and has promised to give Trump the panel’s recommendation this week.White House adviser Jared Kushner voiced strong support for Oracle’s bid

Oracle's strategy of slow and steady to ultimately win the race has always proven successful. The company has top rated apps, top rated technology, produces its own hardware and cloud infrastructure which is a perfect recipe to take orders and scale up very quickly. For shareholders, they've been paying dividends, buying back stock and always looking out for the bottom line while making significant investments in targeted growth areas. Their competitors other than SFDC have not made any significant investments other than improving their existing offerings which Oracle has caught up to or surpassed.The time is now.

I believe ORCL is a sleeping giant and may be at an inflection point here. They have enormous untapped potential in cloud computing. Their net margin is 25 percent, operating margin is 35 percent, gross margin is 80 percent. The company trades at a discount to intrinsic value and that is backed up both by its 14 PE and its nearly 7 percent free cash flow yield. The company has little debt, 43 billion in cash, and 11.6 billion free cash flow. What’s not to like?

DONE DEAL DONE FOR SURE Treasury, Oracle, ByteDance agree on TikTok terms - reportsSep. 17, 2020 11:23 AM ETOracle Corporation (ORCL)By: Jason Aycock, SA News Editor1 CommentThe Treasury Dept., TikTok owner ByteDance (BDNCE) and Oracle (ORCL -1%) have a tentative agreement on terms of the bid for the social media app's U.S. operations, according to media reports.Treasury had revisions for the deal, to which the two companies agreed in full, CNBC says.And while White House Chief of Staff Mark Meadows said President Trump would decide on the deal in 24-36 hours, the new reports are a strong signal of deal approval.

The State of Calif Supreme Court just declined Oracle's appeal to overturn their case against HPE/HPQ. The original jury verdict was for $3 Billion -years ago, and with interest it is now around $4.5 Billion and accruing interest at the rate of $1 Million a day. Oracle lost the jury trial, the Calif. Court of Appeals case, and then Oracle appealed to the Calif. Supreme Court, which yesterday declined to hear. The US Supreme Court turns down the vast majority of cases that are appealed to them. In Oracle's last SEC filing ( 10Q) they did not mention trying to appeal the Calif. Supreme Court's ruling if it went against them. Only said that if the Calif. Supreme Court denied their appeal, it would be a material event.

Like many older tech companies with failure to innovate, Oracle is falling behind in its transition to the cloud, has been in the process of transitioning away from its legacy database business and expensive subscription-base cloud business. In a bid protest filed recently in the U.S. Court of Federal Claims, Oracle argued the Defense Department’s $10 billion cloud-computing contract over 10 years, known as the Joint Enterprise Defense Infrastructure, or “JEDI” for short, has improperly favored Amazon Web Services, the cloud-computing unit of Amazon.com. The lawsuit comes just weeks after the Government Accountability Office ruled against an earlier bid protest by Oracle, which had taken issue with the Pentagon’s approach.The recent departure of 22-year Oracle veteran Thomas Kurian, who was in charge of the company’s product development and a key figure in its cloud efforts, was another red flag for many analysts. Originally, the company had said he was taking extended time off. Then, not too long after, Kurian left and joined Alphabet as the head of Google Cloud.

I'm young, so I haven't the savings to really start investing for my long term future yet- but I'll give those of you long-termers my insight as a young guy, and as cyber/network systems college major. When people think of cloud systems, the first thing they think is backing up pictures, or just general online data storage like Dropbox. Truth is that cloud storage is way more valued then that. Online game servers? Held on cloud systems. Online learning? Held on cloud systems. New apps and digital innovators that need storage but can't afford the internet and storage? They go to cloud companies. Point being is that the cloud is a huge industry, and that is likely a reason why we've seen Microsoft, Amazon, and other companies sky rocket in the last decade. The mistake people are making is that Oracle can't compete. When you charge for cloud storage, your more over charging for a service, not a product. Oracle selling a sought after service leaves very little room for it to underperform.
